learningContent.title: Adding map references to a map

lcInstruction.p: The <mapref> element is structured as follows:
The href attribute contains a link to another map that should be referenced in your main map. The format attribute specifies that you are linking to a DITA map.
The <mapref> element may only contain the <topicmeta>, <data>, and <data-about> metadata elements. You cannot nest <topicref> or <mapref> elements inside a <mapref> element in DITA.

Just as the <topicref> element allows you to reuse the same topic in more than one map, the <mapref> element allows you to reuse a collection of topics. By building a map once and referencing it in other maps, you can save the time and effort it would have taken to re-create the same series or hierarchy of <topicref> elements in multiple maps.

In addition to reuse, the <mapref> element gives you added flexibility when you publish your content. You can group related maps together in a larger map so that you can quickly deliver the content for one product or for an entire product family. You can also use the <mapref> element to add a glossary to a map, as you'll learn to do in the following example.

note.p: This lesson covers basic use of the <mapref> element and the elements it contains. For the full specifications for each element, see the OASIS DITA Version 1.2 Standard.

step.cmd: After the last <topicref> element, add a <mapref> element and add content to it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE map PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Map//EN" "map.dtd"> <map id="ducks"> <title>Ducks</title> ... </topicref> <mapref href="g_duck_glossorg.ditamap" format="ditamap"/> </map>

step.info: This <mapref> element creates a link to the glossary g_duck_glossorg.ditamap. By using the <mapref> element to link to the glossary, you not only avoid the hassle of building the glossary directly in your map using <topicref> elements pointing to individual <glossentry> or <glossgroup> topics, but you also make your glossary more easily available for reuse in other maps.
